interaction_summary:
=== Purchase Information ===
Product Title: Atlas Shrugged: Part One
Review Date: 2012/12/14
Store: Patrick Fischler  (Actor),     Taylor Schilling  (Actor)    Rated:    PG-13    Format: DVD
Categories: Movies & TV, Studio Specials, 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment, All Fox Titles
Product Description: ['Product Description', 'Ayn Rand\'s timeless novel of\xa0rational self-interest\xa0comes to life for a new millennium.". The year is 2016, and America is on the verge of economic disaster. The greatest citizens are being targeted, and dark forces are working to bring about America’s final days. Our only hope for salvation lies with Dagny Taggart and Henry Rearden, rugged individualists whose bold ideas may have the power to spark a revolution and reclaim to the American Dream.', 'Amazon.com', 'After years of trying, somebody finally made a film out of Ayn Rand\'s big-selling novel of "rational self-interest,"', 'Atlas Shrugged', '. Well, got a start on it, anyway, with this 2011 release of', 'Part One', "(of three). The sprawling novel is necessarily telescoped down to size, and the focus is on railroad magnate Dagny Taggart (Taylor Schilling) and her intricate strategies involving a piece of real estate in Colorado, an ongoing economic collapse, and the rugged individualist, Hank Rearden (Grant Bowler), whose new metal alloy might come in handy for laying new track. Of course, the real issue in Rand's scenario is not metal alloy but the fact that government regulation and a misguided sense of collectivism and altruism is strangling the elite members of society, something the movie reminds us of with grim regularity. As a kind of boardroom-plotting movie,", 'Atlas Shrugged', 'isn\'t incompetent, and if director Paul Johansson hasn\'t devised a way to make these heavy-handed discussions come to life, at least it keeps moving along. If you like Rand\'s objectivist philosophy, you\'ll bask in the glow of having those ideas reaffirmed, and if you\'re uninitiated, well, they certainly are laid out there in stark fashion. (And if you find Rand\'s ideas absurd, you\'ll find this movie a little like watching a cult meeting.) As to the question "Who is John Galt?" you\'ll have to move on to', 'Atlas Shrugged: Part Two', ", released in 2012, to pick that up--but be ready to work at sorting the plot out anew, because Part One's cast has been replaced by a new roster of actors.", '--Robert Horton']
Average Rating: 4.1
Product Details: {'Aspect Ratio': '2.35:1', 'Is Discontinued By Manufacturer': 'No', 'MPAA rating': 'PG-13 (Parents Strongly Cautioned)', 'Product Dimensions': '0.6 x 5.3 x 7.5 inches; 2.72 Ounces', 'Item model number': '22914266', 'Director': 'Paul Johansson', 'Media Format': 'Multiple Formats, AC-3, Color, Dolby, NTSC, Subtitled, Widescreen', 'Run time': '1 hour and 37 minutes', 'Release date': 'November 8, 2011', 'Actors': 'Patrick Fischler, Taylor Schilling, Grant Bowler, Matthew Marsden, Edi Gathegi', 'Subtitles': 'English, Spanish', 'Producers': 'Harmon M. Kaslow, John Aglialoro', 'Studio': '20th Century Fox', 'Number of discs': '1'}
Review Text: This is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  The movie reviewers were way off on this flick.  The actors are outstanding. It is happening right now in our nation!  Wake up America and Europe!
Review Title: Look around and smell our future!
Rating: 5.0
--------------------------------------------------
reference_summary:
Atlas Shrugged: Part One
Patrick Fischler  (Actor),     Taylor Schilling  (Actor)    Rated:    PG-13    Format: DVD
Movies & TV, Studio Specials, 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment, All Fox Titles
['Product Description', 'Ayn Rand\'s timeless novel of\xa0rational self-interest\xa0comes to life for a new millennium.". The year is 2016, and America is on the verge of economic disaster. The greatest citizens are being targeted, and dark forces are working to bring about America’s final days. Our only hope for salvation lies with Dagny Taggart and Henry Rearden, rugged individualists whose bold ideas may have the power to spark a revolution and reclaim to the American Dream.', 'Amazon.com', 'After years of trying, somebody finally made a film out of Ayn Rand\'s big-selling novel of "rational self-interest,"', 'Atlas Shrugged', '. Well, got a start on it, anyway, with this 2011 release of', 'Part One', "(of three). The sprawling novel is necessarily telescoped down to size, and the focus is on railroad magnate Dagny Taggart (Taylor Schilling) and her intricate strategies involving a piece of real estate in Colorado, an ongoing economic collapse, and the rugged individualist, Hank Rearden (Grant Bowler), whose new metal alloy might come in handy for laying new track. Of course, the real issue in Rand's scenario is not metal alloy but the fact that government regulation and a misguided sense of collectivism and altruism is strangling the elite members of society, something the movie reminds us of with grim regularity. As a kind of boardroom-plotting movie,", 'Atlas Shrugged', 'isn\'t incompetent, and if director Paul Johansson hasn\'t devised a way to make these heavy-handed discussions come to life, at least it keeps moving along. If you like Rand\'s objectivist philosophy, you\'ll bask in the glow of having those ideas reaffirmed, and if you\'re uninitiated, well, they certainly are laid out there in stark fashion. (And if you find Rand\'s ideas absurd, you\'ll find this movie a little like watching a cult meeting.) As to the question "Who is John Galt?" you\'ll have to move on to', 'Atlas Shrugged: Part Two', ", released in 2012, to pick that up--but be ready to work at sorting the plot out anew, because Part One's cast has been replaced by a new roster of actors.", '--Robert Horton']

This is one of the best movies I have ever seen.  The movie reviewers were way off on this flick.  The actors are outstanding. It is happening right now in our nation!  Wake up America and Europe!
Look around and smell our future!
profile:
The user showcases a strong preference for thought-provoking films that explore themes of individualism and economic philosophy, particularly those aligned with objectivist ideals. Their positive reaction to adaptations of Ayn Rand's work, indicated by a high rating and enthusiastic review, suggests a deep appreciation for narratives that challenge collectivism and highlight personal responsibility. 

Key preferences and trends include:

- **Interest in Philosophical Themes**: The user is drawn to films that engage with complex social and economic concepts, particularly those advocating rational self-interest.
- **High Standards for Storytelling**: They express enjoyment of performances and narratives that resonate with contemporary societal issues, demonstrating a demand for quality in both acting and thematic engagement.
- **Active Engagement with Content**: The user appears to be an advocate for broader awareness regarding the implications of government regulation and collective ideologies, indicative of a proactive, possibly activist mindset.

Overall, the profile indicates a strong alignment towards media that reflects personal empowerment and critiques mainstream societal norms, with a focus on impactful storytelling and compelling performances.
